remarks:
Induction on the integers from ` 0 ` to ` N ` inclusive.  The first four hypotheses give us the substitution instances we need; the last two are the basis and the induction step.  (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 31-Mar-2011.) 

---

 Induction on the integers from ` 0 ` to ` N ` inclusive .  The first four hypotheses give us the substitution instances we need; the last two are the basis and the induction step.  (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 31-Mar-2011.)
statement:
fnn0ind.1 $e |- ( x = 0 -> ( ph <-> ps ) ) $.
fnn0ind.2 $e |- ( x = y -> ( ph <-> ch ) ) $.
fnn0ind.3 $e |- ( x = ( y + 1 ) -> ( ph <-> th ) ) $.
fnn0ind.4 $e |- ( x = K -> ( ph <-> ta ) ) $.
fnn0ind.5 $e |- ( N e. NN0 -> ps ) $.
fnn0ind.6 $e |- ( ( N e. NN0 /\ y e. NN0 /\ y < N ) -> ( ch -> th ) ) $.
fnn0ind $p |- ( ( N e. NN0 /\ K e. NN0 /\ K <_ N ) -> ta ) $.
$d K x $.
$d N x y $.
$d ch x $.
$d ph y $.
$d ps x $.
$d ta x $.
$d th x $.
